chapter.title: Using &cloud; ‐

abstract.para: After a short introduction to the ‐, learn how to execute key tasks such as creating images, managing networks, launching and managing instances, and how to use volumes for persistent storage.

chapter.sect1:
Managing Images
&images;
&img-manage;
Managing images for &productname; requires the following basic steps:
.
For general and hypervisor-specific requirements, refer to .
.
Images can either be uploaded to &productname; with the glance command line tool or with the &productname; ‐. As the ‐ comes with some limitations with regard to image upload and modification of properties, it is recommended to use the glance command line tools for comprehensive image management.
Specifying Image Properties. You can do so during image upload (using glance image-create) or with glance image-update after the image has already been uploaded. Refer to and .
&note-img-props;
Image Properties
&img-props;
Uploading Images
&img-ownership;
Uploading Disk Images to &productname;
As a user, you can only upload or modify images for the projects that you are a member of. Public images can only be uploaded or modified by cloud administrators.
Since the &ostack; Grizzly release, it is possible to upload images also via the ‐. Images can either be uploaded from external URLs or from a local file system. Upload of compressed image binaries (.zip and .tar.gz) is supported.
Limitations for Image Upload via ‐
For upload from an external URL, the image must be available via a valid HTTP URL that leads directly to the image binary. URLs that redirect or serve error pages will result in unusable images.
Avoid upload of large images via ‐. For image sizes of several GB, it is strongly recommended to use the command line tools. For details, refer to .
Only a limited set of image properties are accessible from the ‐. It is therefore recommended to set and modify image properties from the command line. For details, refer to .
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Images .
Click Create Image.
In the window that opens, enter a Name for the image.
If you have an external URL to upload the image from, enter the URL into the Image Location field. (The Image Location field is only available if the Image Source drop-down box is set to Image Location, which is the default on opening the Create an Image dialog).
For a local image to upload, set Image Source to Image File and enter the path into Image File. Alternatively, click Browse to select the file from your file system.
Select the image Format.
Optionally, enter the image's Architecture.
If you want to specify a minimum disk size or minimum RAM size that is required to boot the image, enter the values into the respective input fields. Otherwise the minimums are set to 0.
If you want to make the image available to all projects, activate the Public check box.
To prevent the image from being deleted, activate the Protected check box.
Confirm your changes.
The image is uploaded to the &ostack; &img; service.
After images have been added, they appear in the &cloud; ‐ in Project Compute Images .
&cloud; ‐—List of Images (User's View)
From there, you can also edit some image properties by selecting More Edit . As only a limited set of image properties are accessible from the ‐, it is preferable to set and modify image properties from the command line. For more details, refer to .
&note-img-props;
Updating Images
After having uploaded an image to &cloud;, the image contents cannot be modified—only the image's metadata, see . To update image contents, you need to delete the current image and upload a modified version of the image. You can also launch an instance from the respective image, change it, create a snapshot of the instance and use the snapshot as a new image.
If you need to delete an image, proceed as follows.
Deleting Images
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Images .
To delete one or multiple images, activate the check boxes in front of the images that you want to delete.
Click Delete Images and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

sect1.title: Managing Networks
sect1.para: Use the categories below ProjectNetwork in the left navigation bar to configure virtual networks. &network-role-dependency;
sect1.procedure:
Creating, Modifying or Deleting Networks
&network-def;
As a user, you can only create or modify networks that are not shared and not external and that are part of the project that you belong to. For any other network-related tasks, contact your cloud administrator.
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Network Networks .
To create a new network or modify an existing one:
Click Create Network or select a network and click Edit Network.
In the window that opens, enter a name for your network or change the existing name.
Leave the Admin State check box activated—unless you want the network to be marked as down and to not forward any packets.
To additionally create a subnet to be associated with the new network, refer to .
Confirm your changes to create the new network.
To delete an existing network:
Activate the check boxes in front of the networks that you want to delete.
Click Delete Networks and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
&note-network-delete;

Creating or Modifying Subnets &subnet-intro;
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Network Networks .
Select a network and click its Network Name to view the details for the network.
Click Create Subnet or select a subnet and click Edit Subnet.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the subnet or change the existing name.
Enter or change the Network Address. It must be specified in CIDR format, for example:
192.168.0.0/24
Choose the IP Version to use (IPv4 or IPv6).
If you want to use another Gateway IP than the default one, enter a Gateway IP. Otherwise, leave the input field blank.
If you do not want to use a gateway, activate Disable Gateway.
To specify additional attributes for the subnet, click the Subnet Detail tab and proceed as follows:
Specify whether to Enable DHCP.
To define multiple Allocation Pools, enter the start and the end IP address for each pool separated by a comma and in one entry per line for each pool. For example:
192.168.0.10,192.168.0.50 192.168.0.100,192.168.0.150
To specify DNS Name Servers, enter an IP address list of servers for the current subnet (one entry per line).
For additional routes announced to the hosts, enter them into the Host Routes field as follows: One entry per line, each specifying:
DESTINATION_CIDR,NEXTHOP
Confirm your changes to close the dialog.

Modifying Ports &port-dash-automatics;
&port-intro;
As a user, you can only modify certain port attributes. For any other changes, contact your cloud administrator.
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Network Networks .
Select a network and click its Network Name to view the details for the network.
Select a port to change and click Edit Port.
In the window that opens, change the Name for the port. Its ID is also displayed, but cannot be changed.
Leave the Admin State check box activated—unless you want the port to be marked as down and to not forward any traffic.
Confirm your changes to close the dialog.

Creating or Modifying Routers &router-intro;
To add a router and to connect an external network to an internal one:
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Network Routers .
Click Create Router.
In the window that opens, enter a Router Name and confirm your choice.
The Routers category shows the newly created router.
To connect an external network to the router:
Click Set Gateway for the newly created router.
In the window that opens, select the External Network which to connect to the router and confirm your choice.
To connect a subnet to the router:
Click the router's name to view the Router Details.
Click Add Interface.
In the window that opens, select the Subnet which to connect to the router and confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
After having created a new router and having connected it to an external network and a gateway, you can view a graphical representation of the network topology by switching to ProjectNetwork Network Topology .

chapter.sect1:
Launching Instances &instances;
Key Parameters
When starting an instance, specify the following key parameters:
Flavor &flavors;
For more details and a list of default flavors available, refer to .
Key Pair (optional, but recommended) &keypairs;
For details, refer to .
Security Group &security;
For details, refer to .
Network
Instances can belong to one or multiple networks. By default, each instance is given a fixed IP address, belonging to the internal network.
Boot Source of the Instance &instance-boot-source;
If needed, you can assign a floating (public) IP address to a running instance and attach a block storage device (volume) for persistent storage. For details, refer to and .
Launching Instances From Images
You can start an instance directly from one of the images available in &ostack; &img;. In that case, &productname; will create a local copy of the image on the respective &compnode; where the instance will be started.
Launching an Instance from an Image
The &cloud; ‐ shows the images that have been uploaded to &ostack; &img; and are available for this project on the Images category within the Project category.
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Instances and click Launch Instance to open the respective dialog.
&cloud; ‐—Launch Instance, Details Tab
On its Details tab, specify the following parameters:
Select the Availability Zone from which to start the instance. Only &compnode;s belonging to this zone are eligible to run this particular instance.
Enter an Instance Name that will be assigned to the virtual machine.
From the Flavor drop-down box, select the size of the virtual machine to launch. &note-hyperv-flavor;
In Instance Count, enter the number of virtual machines to launch from this image.
Depending on which ‐ category you opened the Launch Instance dialog from, the value of Instance Boot Source might automatically be preselected. Click the drop-down box to choose between the following values:
Boot from image—see
Boot from volume—see
Boot from snapshot—see
Boot from image (creates a new volume)
Boot from volume snapshot (creates a new volume)
The value of Instance Boot Source also defines which additional parameters appear below.
To launch an instance from an image that is available in &ostack; &img;, make sure Instance Boot Source is set to Boot from image. From the Image Name drop-down box, select which image to boot.
Switch to the Access & Security tab. &cloud; ‐—Launch Instance, Access & Security Tab
There, specify the following parameters:
Select a Key Pair. For details, refer to . In case an image uses a static &rootuser; password or a static key set (neither is recommended), you do not need to provide a key pair on starting the instance.
Activate the Security Groups that you want to assign to the instance. Security groups are a kind of cloud firewall that define which incoming network traffic should be forwarded to instances. For details, refer to .
If you have not created any specific security groups, you can only assign the instance to the default security group. After the instance has been launched, you can still change the security group or groups assigned to the instance.
Switch to the Networking tab.
&cloud; ‐—Launch Instance, Networking Tab
There, specify to which network the instance should belong:
Move one or multiple of the Available Networks to the Selected Networks field by clicking the plus icon next to the network.
Choice of Available Networks
As long as you do not have configured a pool of floating IP addresses yet, Available Networks only shows the internal network with fixed IPs. For details about configuring floating IPs, refer to .
If you have specified multiple networks in the Selected Networks field, change their order by drag and drop, if necessary. taroth 2014-07-14: there are two additional tabs: " Post-Creation" and "Advanced Options"
With this, you have set all key parameters for launching an instance. Click Launch Instance. The instance will be started on any of the &compnode;s in the cloud that belong to the selected availability zone.
&instance-launch-post;
Launching Instances from Volumes
You can start an instance directly from one of the images available in &ostack; &img; or from an image that you have copied to a persistent volume before. To transfer an image to the volume, either directly create a volume from an image that is available in &ostack; &img; or manually copy an image to the volume as described in .
Manually Preparing a Bootable Volume
The following steps describe how to create an empty volume and manually copy an image to it. Alternatively, for directly creating a volume from an image, refer to .
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Create an empty volume as described in . Its size must be large enough to store an unzipped image.
Create an image with &susestudio; or &suseonsite;. For details, refer to .
To be able to copy the image to the empty volume, you need to execute the following steps first:
Launch an instance from an arbitrary image as described in .
Which image you select there is only important if you want to boot a &xen; image from the volume later on. In that case, the image you select in of needs to be of the same type as the one on the volume: fully virtualized or paravirtualized.
In any other case the image you select for starting the instance does not matter. It will be replaced by the image on the volume that you specify in of .
Make sure to select an appropriate flavor for the instance. The instance's hard disk must be big enough to store the image that you want to copy onto the volume later on.
Attach the empty volume to the running instance as described in .
Copy the image that you created in to the running instance (for example, by using scp).
Log in to the instance by using SSH or the VNC console.
Assuming that the attached volume is mounted as /dev/vdb, use one of the following commands to copy the image to the attached volume:
For a raw image: cat IMAGE >/dev/vdb
(alternatively, use dd)
For a non-raw image: qemu-img convert -O raw IMAGE /dev/vdb
For a *.tar.bz2 image: tar xfjO IMAGE >/dev/vdb
As the image comes with a predefined disk size (that might be smaller than the size of the volume it has been copied to), the image will not use the full size of the volume. To change this, adjust the partition table within the image to match the size of the volume.
As only detached volumes are available for booting, detach the volume. For details on how to do so, refer to , .
Now, you can launch an instance from the image that has been copied to the volume. The instance will be booted from the volume, which is provided by &ostack; &blockstore; through iSCSI. To do so, proceed with .
Launching an Instance from a Volume
When booting an image from a volume, the procedure is basically the same as when launching an instance from an image in &ostack; &img;, except for some additional steps.
Follow to from .
On the Details tab of the Launch Instance dialog, specify the following options to boot from a volume:
Set Instance Boot Source to Boot from Volume.
In Volume, select the volume to launch the instance from.
Switch to the other tabs and set the required options as described in , to .
&instance-launch-post;
Launching Instances from Snapshots
In addition to launching instances directly from images available in &productname;, or from volumes that contain an image, you can also launch an instance from an instance snapshot or a volume snapshot.
Launching an Instance from a Snapshot

Configuring Access to the Instances &inst-access-params;
Configuring Security Groups and Rules &security;
Security Groups &sec-groups;
Creating or Deleting Security Groups
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project ComputeAccess & Security . The view shows the following tabs: Security Groups, Key Pairs, Floating IPs, and API Access.
To create a new security group:
Select the Security Groups tab and click Create Security Group.
In the window that opens, enter a Name and Description for the group and confirm your changes.
To delete one or multiple security groups:
Activate the check boxes in front of the groups that you want to delete.
Click Delete Security Groups and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
&note-groups-delete;
&cloud; ‐—List of Security Groups
Security Group Rules &sec-rules;
&sec-rules-params;
&security-default;
Configuring Security Group Rules
For quicker configuration, the ‐ provides templates for rules that are often-used, including rules for well-known protocols on top of TCP (such as HTTP or SSH), or rules to allow all ICMP traffic (for pings).
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Click Project Compute Access & Security . The view shows the following tabs: Security Groups, Key Pairs, Floating IPs, and API Access.
On the Security Group tab, click Manage Rules for the security group you want to modify. This opens the Security Group Rules screen that shows the existing rules for the group and lets you add or delete rules.
Click Add Rule to open a new dialog.
From the Rule drop-down box, you can select templates for rules that are often-used, including rules for well-known protocols on top of TCP (such as HTTP or SSH), or rules to allow all ICMP traffic (for pings). In the following steps, we will focus on the most commonly-used rules only:
To enable SSH access to the instances:
Set Rule to SSH.
Decide whether to allow traffic to instances only from IP addresses inside the cloud (from other group members) or from all IP addresses.
To enable access from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0), leave the Remote and CIDR fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, set Remote to Security Group. Select the desired Security Group and Ether Type (IPv4 or IPv6).
To enable pinging the instances:
Set Rule to ALL ICMP.
Decide whether to allow traffic to instances only from IP addresses inside the cloud (from other group members) or from all IP addresses.
To enable access from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0), leave the Remote and CIDR fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, set Remote to Security Group. Select the desired Security Group and Ether Type (IPv4 or IPv6).
To enable access via a UDP port (for example, for syslog):
Set Rule to Custom UDP.
Leave the Direction and Open Port values untouched.
In the Port input field, enter the value 514.
Decide whether to allow traffic to instances only from IP addresses inside the cloud (from other group members) or from all IP addresses.
To enable access from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0), leave the Remote and CIDR fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, set Remote to Security Group. Select the desired Security Group and Ether Type (IPv4 or IPv6).
&cloud; ‐—List of Security Group Rules
Deleting Security Group Rules
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Click Project Compute Access & Security . The view shows the following tabs: Security Groups, Key Pairs, Floating IPs, and API Access.
On the Security Group tab, select the security group to modify and click Manage Rules. This opens the Security Group Rules screen that shows the existing rules for the group and lets you add or delete rules.
Select the rule or rules to remove.
Click Delete Rules and confirm your choice.
Creating or Importing Keys &keypairs;
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Click Project Compute Access & Security . The view shows the following tabs: Security Groups, Key Pairs, Floating IPs, and API Access.
Switch to the Key Pairs tab.
To import a key pair that you have generated with an external tool:
Click Import Key Pair.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the key pair and copy the public key into the respective input field.
Confirm your choice.
To create a new key pair:
Click Create Key Pair.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the key pair and confirm your choice.
&ostack; generates a key pair and provides the private key for download as a *.pem file.
Save the *.pem file locally and change its permissions so that only you can read and write to the file:
chmod 600 MY_PRIV_KEY.pem
The public key of the key pair is registered in the ∁ database. The ‐ lists the key pair in the Access & Security category as shown in .
Access from a Windows Machine
If you want to access an instance via SSH from a Windows* machine, you need to convert the key from *.pem format to *.ppk format after downloading it. To do so, use PuTTY Key Generator (PuTTYgen) on a Windows workstation:
Download PuTTY Key Generator from the Internet.
Open the puttygen.exe file.
Click Load to open the *.pem file.
Save as public-private key (*.ppk).
&cloud; ‐—Key Pairs
Managing IP Addresses &ip-addr; Allocating Floating (Public) IPs to a Project &ip-allocate;
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Click Project Compute Access & Security . The view shows the following tabs: Security Groups, Key Pairs, Floating IPs, and API Access.
To allocate a floating IP address to the current project:
Switch to the Floating IPs tab.
Click Allocate IP to Project.
In the window that opens, select a Pool out of which to take the IP address.
Click Allocate IP.
The ‐ shows the allocated IP addresses for the project on the Floating IPs tab.
To release one or multiple floating IP addresses from a project:
Activate the check boxes in front of the IP addresses that you want to release.
Click Release Floating IPs. The IP addresses are put back into the pool of IP addresses that are available for all projects. If an IP address is currently assigned to a running instance, it will automatically be disassociated from the instance.
Assigning Floating (Public) IP Addresses to Instances &ip-assign;
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Click Project Compute Access & Security . The view shows the following tabs: Security Groups, Key Pairs, Floating IPs, and API Access.
Switch to the Floating IPs tab.
To assign an IP to an instance:
From the list of Floating IPs, select the IP that you want to use for the instance and click Associate.
In the window that opens, the current IP address is preselected in the IP Address drop-down box. The drop-down box Port to be associated shows a list of running instances with the respective fixed IP address.
From Port to be associated select the instance to associate with the floating IP address.
Confirm your choices.
In the Access & Security category, the Floating IPs tab shows the name of the instance with which the IP has been associated. The instance is now publicly available under the respective floating IP address (provided you have also configured the security group rules for the instance accordingly). For details, refer to .
To remove a floating IP address from an instance:
On the Floating IPs tab, select the IP address to remove.
Click Disassociate and confirm your change.
Floating IPs can also be assigned to or removed from instances from the Instances category by selecting the respective menu entry from the More drop-down box for an instance.
However, which floating IP is assigned to an instance can best be viewed in the Access & Security category.

Select Project Compute Instances .
Select the instance and from the More drop-down list, select View Log.
Alternatively, click the instance's name and switch to the Log tab that opens.
The ‐ shows the output of the instance's serial console.

sect1.sect2:
Accessing Instances from Remote
The ‐'s built-in VNC client lets you access instances at any time.
Accessing an Instance via VNC
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Instances .
Select the instance to access and from the More drop-down box, select Console.
Alternatively, click the instance's name and switch to the Console tab that opens.
When establishing the first connection, you might be prompted by your browser to trust a certificate before you can see the VNC screen.
In this case, ask your cloud operator for the certificate details to verify the certificate.
If the console should not respond to keyboard input, follow the instructions on the screen.
To display a larger VNC screen, use the link Click here to show only console.
To leave the large VNC screen, use the back button of the browser.
&ssh-req;

sect2.title: Resizing Instances
sect2.para: You can resize a running instance by choosing a different flavor for the instance:

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Instances .
Select the instance to resize. From the More drop-down box, select Resize. A dialog opens that shows the Old Flavor that has been assigned to the instance.
Select a New Flavor and click Resize.
The Status column of the instance changes its value several times until the Confirm Resize/Migrate button appears in the Action column.
To execute the size change of the instance, click Confirm Resize/Migrate. Otherwise click More Revert Resize/Migrate to abort the process.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

sect1.sect2:
Using Instance Snapshots &inst-snap;
As snapshots capture the state of the file system, but not the state of the memory, consider the following guidelines before taking snapshots: .
&note-change-keypairs;
Creating Instance Snapshots
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Instances .
Click Create Snapshot next to the instance that you want to snapshot.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the snapshot and confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the new snapshot in the Images & Snapshot category.
&diff-snapshot-image;
To launch a new instance from the snapshot, select the snapshot and click Launch. Proceed with launching an instance as described in .
&cloud; ‐—List of Images & Snapshots

sect2.title: Tracking Usage
sect2.para: Use the ‐'s Overview category to track usage of instances per project. This lets you track costs per time period by showing metrics like number of VCPUs, disks, RAM, and uptime of all your instances. The upper part of the Overview screen also shows a graphical representation of your quota values for the project.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Overview .
S In Select a period of time to query its usage, enter a start and end date for the period and click Submit.
The Usage Summary table shows the results of your query and displays metrics like the number of VCPUs, disks, RAM, and uptime of all your instances. It also lets you download a CVS summary.

chapter.sect1:
Managing Volumes &volumes;
Creating or Deleting Volumes
When creating volumes, you can choose between the following options:
Creating an empty volume.
Using an image in &ostack; &img; as source for the volume.
Using a volume snapshot as source for the volume.
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Volumes .
To create a volume:
Click Create Volume.
In the window that opens, enter a Volume Name to assign to a volume, a description (optional), and define the size in GB.
If a volume type has been defined by a cloud administrator, select the desired Type from the drop-down box. A volume type specifies the capabilities of the storage back-end drivers to be used.
From the Volume Source drop-down box, specify whether to create an empty volume, or whether to use an image or a volume snapshot as source.
If you chose to use a source, specify which image or volume snapshot to use.
Confirm your changes.
The ‐ shows the volume in the Volumes category.
To delete one or multiple volumes:
Activate the check boxes in front of the volumes that you want to delete.
Click Delete Volumes and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears. Volumes that are attached to an instance cannot be deleted.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
&vol-attach; View the Status of a volume in the Volumes category of the ‐: the Attached To column tells you if the volume is still available or already in use.
&cloud; ‐—List of Volumes
Attaching Volumes to Instances
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Volumes .
Select the volume to add to an instance and click
More Edit Attachments .
In the window that opens, select an instance to attach the volume to.
Enter a Device Name under which the volume should be accessible on the virtual machine.
&note-kvm-device-name;
Confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the instance to which the volume has been attached and the volume's device name.
Now you can log in to the instance, mount the disk, format it (if necessary), and use it.
Instances Running Older Kernel Versions
If one of the instances runs a Kernel version that was shipped prior to &sle; 11 SP2, you need to reboot the instance to make the device appear.
For instances running the &sls; SP2 Kernel (or later), it is enough to load the acpiphp module manually:
modprobe acpiphp
To detach a volume from an instance:
Select the volume and click More Edit Attachments .
In the window that opens, click Detach Volume and confirm your changes.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
Creating Volume Snapshots &vol-snap;
Log in to &cloud; ‐ and select a project from the drop-down box at the top-level row.
Select Project Compute Volumes .
Check if the volume of which to create a snapshot is Attached To an instance. If yes, click Edit Attachments, click Detach Volume in the window that opens and confirm your choice.
From the More drop-down box, select Create Snapshot.
In the window that opens, enter a Snapshot Name and a Description.
Confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the new Volume Snapshot in the Volumes & Snapshots category.
&cloud; ‐—List of Volumes & Snapshots

Migrating Instances &migration;
Migrating Instances (Offline Migration)
The ‐ currently only enables you to execute offline migrations. For live migrations, use the command line tools as described in .
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Compute Instances .
Select the instance to migrate and click More Migrate Instance .
The Status column of the instance changes its value several times until the Confirm Resize/Migrate button appears in the Action column.
To execute the migration, click Confirm Resize/Migrate. Otherwise click More Revert Resize/Migrate to abort the migration process.
After the migration has finished, the instance's IP Address is updated in the Instances category.

sect1.title: Managing &objstore; Containers and Objects
sect1.para: &ostack; &objstore; provides a distributed, API-accessible storage platform that can be used to store any type of file (for example, VM images, backups, archives, or media files) or to be integrated directly into an application.

In the ‐, you can only manage containers and objects. Containers provide storage for objects in a manner similar to a Windows folder or Linux directory, though they cannot be nested. An object consists of the file to be stored in the container and any accompanying metadata.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Object Store Containers .
Enter a Container Name and define the accessibility of the container (public or private).
Confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
To delete a container, select More Delete Container .
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Object Store Containers .
Click the name of the container in which you want to store an object.
Click Upload Object.
Enter an Object Name.
Click Browse and select the file to upload from your file system.
Confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
To delete an object, select More Delete Object .
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

procedure.title: Copying an Object from One Container to Another

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Object Store Containers .
Click the name of the container from which you want to copy an object.
The objects stored in the container are shown on the right side.
Select the object to copy and click More Copy .
In the dialog that opens, select a Destination Container to copy the object to.
Keep or adjust the automatically proposed Destination Object Name according to your wishes.
Confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

procedure.title: Creating a Metadata-only Object
procedure.para: It is also possible to create an empty object that only contains metadata. You can add a file later on.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Object Store Containers .
Click the name of the container in which you want to create an object.
Click Upload Object.
Enter an Object Name for the file to upload to the container.
Click Browse and select the file from your file system.
Leave the File text box empty and confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
To upload a file later on or to change the object's name, select the object and click Edit.

procedure.title: Creating a Pseudo-folder
procedure.para: Pseudo-folders can be used for grouping objects within a container and are similar to directories in your operating system. Like in a file system, it is also possible to create further subfolders. All pseudo-folders are virtual collections defined by a common prefix on the object's name.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Object Store Containers .
Click the name of the container in which you want to create a pseudo-folder.
Click Create Pseudo-folder and enter a name for the folder.
Confirm your choice.

The pseudo-folder is shown on the right, together with the other objects that belong to the same container. To discriminate them from other objects, the names of pseudo-folders are displayed as links.
To create further subfolders, click the name of the pseudo-folder that you want to use as parent directory and repeat .
When clicking a pseudo-folder, the Folder Path to this folder is shown.

sect1.title: Managing Stacks
sect1.para: The &orch; module enables you to orchestrate multiple composite cloud applications. This module supports use of both the Amazon Web Services (AWS) CloudFormation template format and the native &ostack; Heat Orchestration Template (HOT) format. These flexible template languages enable application developers to describe and automate the deployment of infrastructure, services, and applications. With the templates, most &ostack; resource types, such as instances, floating IP addresses, volumes, security groups, and users, can be created. After having been created, the resources are referred to as stacks.

The template languages are described in the Template Guide, available from . When launching a stack, the templates used for creating the stack can either be specified by referring to a URL, by referring to a file or by entering raw contents for the template into a text box.

procedure.title: Launching, Modifying or Deleting Stacks
procedure.para: To launch a stack, you first need to define which template (and optionally, which environment) to use, and then specify some further options like a name for the stack.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
Select Projects Orchestration Stacks .
Click Launch Stack.
In the window that opens, select a Template Source.
Depending on the choice of the template source, either specify a Template URL, a Template File or enter template code into the Template Data text box.
If you need additional settings for the stack, select an Environment Source.
Depending on the choice of the environment source, either specify an Environment URL, an Environment File or enter raw contents of the environment file into the Environment Data text box.
Click Next.
In the Launch Stack view, specify the following:

listitem.para: In Creation Timeout (minutes), specify the number of minutes that can elapse before the launch of the stack times out.
Activate the Rollback on Failure check box if you want the service to roll back changes if the stack fails to launch.
Specify the password for the user that is currently logged in and is about to launch the stack. It will be used for operations performed through the lifecycle of the stack.

step.para: Confirm your choice.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
To modify the template that is used for the stack, click More Change Stack Template .
To delete one or multiple stacks:
Activate the check boxes in front of the stacks that you want to delete.
Click Delete Stacks and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
